text: today on the caucus Megan Liberman and
Michael Cooper on the political
landscape with economic unease and high
disapproval of congress also Manny
Fernandez reports from Texas on a prayer
event being headlined by possible
presidential candidate Rick Perry what I
want the American people and our
partners around the world to know is
this we are going to get through this
things will get better and we're going
to get there together so Michael the
stock market took a nosedive yesterday
and as our colleague Mike share points
out this morning that's really been the
one positive economic indicator the
president's had 2.2 amid a lot of bad
economic number since he's been in
office and that took a big hit yesterday
right i mean the stock market lost 500
points it's down almost you're a little
more than ten percent in two weeks you
know the stock market is still higher
than it was when President Obama took
office but a lot of people are feeling
it a lot of 401 k's are down down today
and people are going to be upset about
it we also had some job numbers today
which were slightly better than expected
but still really weak the unemployment
rate ticked down to 9.1 percent but 9.1
percent all these months in is still an
astonishingly high number of unemployed
people in this country yeah and we have
a new poll which actually shows that
Americans really want people in
government to stop talking about cutting
and start focusing on jobs right it was
an interesting poll we took it in the
wake of the whole debt ceiling debate
right which was all about how much
should we be cutting and the poll had
some slightly contradictory conclusions
I think there's a sense among people
that even though there's a long-term
deficit problem there's a problem they
want to focus on right now there's a
short-term jobs crisis right and they
weren't exactly thrilled with where the
president was on it but there are a lot
happier with where he was then where the
Congress was in particularly
congressional Republicans right it was
sort of astonishing and in this poll
found in eighty-two percent disapproval
of Congress which is the first we've
ever had since the times has been asking
the question since 1977 it's higher than
it was after the government shutdown
it's higher than it was after the
impeachment of Bill Clinton people were
really mad and when when you broke it
down further it was a Republican to the
most of their i er I mean seventy two
percent disapprove the way
a house republicans handled this they
weren't crazy about House Democrats
sixty-six percent didn't like them but
they were a lot more positive about the
president I mean I think only
forty-seven percent disapproved with the
wasteland was pretty equal yes evenly
split and they the public also does seem
to endorse sort of Warren the approach
to the budget going forward that the
president's been endorsing which is a
sort of balanced approach which includes
tax hikes on wealthy people especially
right i mean half of the people we
polled said that this past debt ceiling
deal should have included some revenue
increases which the republicans blocked
and then going forward a majority of
every party Democrats independents and
Republicans all said that they should
raise taxes on households making more
than two hundred fifty thousand dollars
a year which the president has been
trying to do and he's been stymied by
Congress right so that is something for
him to campaign on but and and his
picture doesn't look as bad compared to
congressional Republicans but they're
not who he's running against he's gotta
run against against people who are
running from outside the Republican
Party and if the economy still where it
is now in 12 months he's got problems
right and there's only so much a
president can do about the economy I
mean and his hands are particularly tied
now even if he wants to push for another
stimulus package he'll have a very hard
time selling this Congress on it so you
know if the economy looks like this any
incumbent would have a hard time running
for real life
potential presidential candidate Rick
Perry is headlining what is likely to be
a closely watched event this weekend
Governor Perry of Texas announced in
June that he was going to invite
governor's from around the country and
people from around the country to join
him in a day of prayer and fasting at
Reliant Stadium in Houston it's been a
pretty controversial event there's been
the usual outrage from the usual
quarters but also the criticism lately
has been a little bit more widespread
there are a number of Methodist pastors
and leaders who have criticized the
governor for this event they don't feel
that this is in the best traditions of
the Methodist faith it's a very unusual
event the governor has sort of almost
said as much you have the governor of
the second largest state in the country
creating promoting a Christian centered
event having said that there are many
people in Texas who don't see the big
deal a lot of people in Texas equate
this event with the National Prayer
Breakfast that happens in Washington
every year Governor Perry has been sort
of adamant that the timing of this event
and the timing of him considering
running for president is completely
coincidental this event sets him on a
national stage sort of unlike anything
he's been on before it will be attended
by supporters and detractors and
numerous reporters Rick Perry and his
faith and his political ambitions will
be under a microscope on Saturday unlike
any he's ever been under
